For any square integrable function , it can be expanded by these eigenfunctions as

rendering .

Substituting coefficients into this equation, we have
$$
\mathscr F_\alpha f(x)= \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \underbrace{\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{e^{jn\alpha}}{2^nn!\sqrt{n}} H_n(x^\prime)H_n(x)}{T(x,x^\prime)} \exp\left(-(x^{\prime 2}+x^2)/2\right)f(x^\prime)dx^\prime
$$
Due to the proposal by Morse (1953), we have

Hence, this equation can be rewritten as
$$
\mathscr F_a f(x)=\frac{\exp(j(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\alpha}{2}))}{\sqrt{2\pi\sin\alpha}}\exp\left(-\frac{j}{2}\cot\alpha x^2\right) \int{\infty}^{\infty}\exp\left(-\frac{j}{2}\cot\alpha x^{\prime 2}+ \frac{jxx^\prime}{\sin\alpha}\right) f(x^\prime) dx^\prime.
$$

A.2. Tridiagonal of

Given the matrices and as follows:

The entries (base 0) of can be expressed as
$$
[\mathbf S]{m,n}=\left[ 2\cos(2\pi m/N)-4 \right]\delta(m-n)+\delta(m-n-1)+\delta(m-n+1).
$$
Therefore, is given by $[\mathbf P\mathbf S\mathbf P]{m,n}=[\mathbf{PS}]{m,:}\mathbf p_n$
[\mathbf {PS}]{m,:} = ,\quad N\text{ even}
$$

$$
[\mathbf {PS}]{m,:} = \begin{cases}
\mathbf s_0^T, & m=0\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\mathbf s_m^T+\mathbf s{N-m}^T), & m\le \lfloor N/2 \rfloor\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} (\mathbf s_{N-m}^T-\mathbf s_m^T) , & m > \lfloor N/2 \rfloor
\end{cases},\quad N\text{ odd}
$$

$$
[\mathbf {PSP}]{m,n} = \begin{cases}
\mathbf s_m^T\mathbf p_n, & m=0,N/2\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\mathbf s_m^T+\mathbf s{N-m}^T)\mathbf p_n, & m < N/2 \
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} (\mathbf s_{N-m}^T-\mathbf s_m^T)\mathbf p_n , & m > N/2
\end{cases},\quad N\text{ even}
$$

$$
[\mathbf {PSP}]{m,n} =
\begin{cases}
\mathbf s_0^T\mathbf p_n, & m=0\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\mathbf s_m^T+\mathbf s{N-m}^T)\mathbf p_n, & m\le \lfloor N/2 \rfloor\
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} (\mathbf s_{N-m}^T-\mathbf s_m^T)\mathbf p_n , & m > \lfloor N/2 \rfloor
\end{cases},\quad N\text{ odd}
$$
